ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned about many different poets from the 1600-2000s. I developed skills on understand writing about poetry. I learned strong close reading skills.
Gained English poetry knowledge and developed poetry analysis skills.

I developed an appreciation for Milton, Pope, Wordsworth, Eliot, and Yeats, as well as Elizabeth Bishop, Gwendolyn Brooks, Louise Glck, and Jericho Brown. My reading, writing, and class participation skills also improved.
I developed close reading skills and learned about the history of poetry.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths in reading and discussing great poetry. Could be improved by more open class discussion.

This is a lovely course. It was my first course in the English department, and I really enjoyed it. It was nice to spend enough time on each poet that I felt I really knew something about each one, while also still fitting in many different voices and times into a single semester. Professor Brisman led very interesting discussions, and, due to the small class size, by the end of the semester I felt everyone our class knew one another. I also appreciated Professor Brisman's openness to reading and providing feedback on essay drafts; I feel like I learn more when I have the opportunity to not only receive feedback on essays, but incorporate that feedback into an improved version of the essay.

I really enjoyed the readings and the class environment. I also felt that all of the assignments were clear, well structured, and meaningful. I sometimes wanted to discuss more of the reading in class; class discussions would often only focus on a small section of what we read on our own, and especially for the contemporary poets, I wish we'd had fewer poems to read each night and spent more class time on each individual one.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend because while the class has a high workload and the comments on essays are very harsh at times, you learn a lot of close reading and essay writing skills.
I would recommend it to anyone wanting a primer in English poetry.

Absolutely. This was a wonderful class; we spent enough time on each poet that I felt I really took something away about each one, but we still fit a lot of different poets into a single semester. Professor Brisman led interesting discussions with lots of great stories, and, due to the small class size, I felt everyone our class knew one another by the end of the semester. Professor Brisman was also open to reading and providing feedback on essay drafts, which I found very helpful.

I would recommend this course to any student with an interest in poetry. I learned a lot from the assigned material and thoroughly enjoyed the readings, and class discussions were dynamic and engaging.
